history.text: In which city was the ancient Colosseum built?
Which empire built a long wall in northern China now known as the Great Wall?
Which famous ship sank in 1912 on its first voyage after hitting an iceberg?
Who is often called the "Maid of Orléans" for her role in the Hundred Years' War?
Which ancient civilization built the pyramids at Giza?
The city of Machu Picchu is linked to which civilization?
Which famous scientist formulated the theory of relativity?
Which revolution in the late 18th century led to the fall of the monarchy in France?
Which ancient city was destroyed by a volcanic eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE?
Which conflict was later called World War I?
The Silk Road mainly connected Europe with which broad region?
Which empire was ruled for a long time from Constantinople, later called Istanbul?
Which 15th-century invention in Europe greatly increased the spread of printed books?
The "Black Death" that struck Europe in the 14th century was mainly which disease?
Which leader carried out large military campaigns across Europe in the early 19th century?
Which early civilization developed in the region between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers?
Which event in 1929 triggered a worldwide economic crisis often called the Great Depression?
options: Stock market crash in New York

history.text: Which African country resisted full European colonization and won the Battle of Adwa in 1896?
Which 20th-century conflict is strongly associated with trench warfare on the Western Front?
Which ancient code of laws is associated with a Babylonian ruler and the phrase "an eye for an eye"?
Which event in June 1914 is often seen as the spark that started World War I?
Which alliance in 1914 included France, Russia and the United Kingdom?
Which countries were the main members of the Central Powers in World War I?
Which new weapon was first used on a large scale in World War I, causing severe injuries in the trenches?
The Western Front in World War I is strongly associated with which kind of warfare?
Which ocean liner was sunk by a German submarine in 1915, increasing tensions with the United States?
Which empire collapsed at the end of World War I, leading to the creation of several new states in Central and Eastern Europe?
Which treaty in 1919 formally ended the war between Germany and the Allied Powers after World War I?
Which new international organization was created after World War I to promote peace and cooperation?
Which empire's disintegration after World War I reshaped the Middle East with new mandates and borders?
Which revolution in 1917 led to the withdrawal of Russia from World War I?
Which front in World War I saw major fighting between Russia and the Central Powers?
Which battle in 1916 became one of the bloodiest of World War I, with huge casualties on both sides?
In World War I, which country switched sides in 1915 from its previous alliance to join the Allies?
Which pandemic in 1918–1919 infected large parts of the world while World War I was ending?
Which ideology, promising order and national revival, rose in several countries after the instability that followed World War I?
World War II is generally considered to have begun in Europe with which event in 1939?
Which countries formed the core of the Axis Powers in World War II?
Which alliance in World War II included the United States, Soviet Union, and United Kingdom?
Which surprise attack in December 1941 led to the United States entering World War II?
Which political movement under Adolf Hitler ruled Germany during World War II?
The systematic murder of six million Jews and millions of other victims by Nazi Germany is known as what?
Which country suffered a brutal invasion by Germany in 1941 under the code name Operation Barbarossa?
Which 1940 air campaign was fought mainly over British cities and is known as the Battle of Britain?
options: German Luftwaffe vs Royal Air Force
US Air Force vs Japanese Navy
Italian Air Force vs Greek Air Force

history.text: Which North African battle in 1942 marked a turning point against German and Italian forces there?
Which decisive 1942–1943 battle on the Eastern Front stopped the German advance into the Soviet Union?
Which major amphibious invasion by Allied forces began on 6 June 1944 in Normandy, France?
Which two Japanese cities were hit by atomic bombs in August 1945?
Which conference in 1945 involved leaders Churchill, Roosevelt, and Stalin planning the postwar order?
Which international organization was founded in 1945 after World War II to promote peace and cooperation?
Which agreement in 1938 allowed Nazi Germany to annex the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia?
Which non-aggression pact in 1939 secretly divided parts of Eastern Europe between Germany and the Soviet Union?
Which volunteer and colonial troops from Africa, Asia and other regions fought for European powers in World War II?
options: Large numbers of troops from colonies as well

history.text: Which island battles in the Pacific, such as Guadalcanal and Iwo Jima, were important in pushing back Japanese forces?
options: They were key stages in the island-hopping strategy
They occurred only after Japan surrendered

history.text: Which large-scale killing of prisoners of war and civilians by the Japanese army occurred in the Chinese city of Nanjing in 1937–1938?
Which resistance movements operated in occupied Europe during World War II, sabotaging Axis forces and helping Allied armies?
options: Various partisan and underground resistance groups

history.text: Which postwar trials held in a German city prosecuted leading Nazi officials for war crimes and crimes against humanity?
Which economic and political division that emerged after World War II is often called the beginning of the Cold War?
options: Tension between Western Allies and the Soviet Union
Renewed alliance of all wartime powers
Return to prewar colonial order without change

history.text: Which large-scale bombing campaign during World War II devastated many German and Japanese cities?
options: Strategic bombing by Allied air forces
